Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2008 01:33PM sue_blue wrote: Tender, It made me so sad to have you gone. I felt like your wisdom and comments were the most valuable thing I got from this sight. I didn't add to those who had posted earlier because they already seemed to say everything that I felt. I am so hopeful and heartened to hear that you will be back. You do truly make this sight seem like part of a sisterhood and you are the someone who truly cares. I have tears of joy at the thought of you being a part of this again. I thought I could get help from your past posts and touch your spirit in a way there, but that was a sad disappointment also. I hope you will be successful and be able to have those restored. I know I for one am still so scared for what is yet to come and you were truly a source of encouragement. I'm so encouraged that you have reconsidered and will be joining us again. Bless you for touching the lives of so many. Susan

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 07:55PM sue_blue wrote: Just finished taxol#5; only two left and I can be doing your "Happy Dance". I can't wait. Now it is waiting for the the se's to take effect. Usually the entire first week has aches and pain, bone pain, and nueropathy, so.. we'll se this time. I can't imagine going topless at this point. I'm thinking it may be summer with a ball cap and maybe if there is enough hair of my own school next fall. We''l have to see about that before I walk in a bldg with over 1000 middle schoolers. Congratualions to everyone's milestones. Keep letting us know what you know about the future and who it is going. Any yes, where is Karyll? Susan
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 11:37AM sue_blue wrote: Evy--I agree with the others... do everything you can to find some help. You are trying to carry way too heavy of a load all by yourself. Your health and your family are your first priority, although with such little ones that in itself is a lot. There has to be someone or a group of some type that can help you. Maybe the local chapter of the Cancer Society; don't be afraid to just tell them in plain language that you need help. Maybe the oncology clinic has connections of some help for you. I wish I could do something to help you. You're in my thoughts and prayers. Let us know how you are doing whenever you can. (((HUGS))) Susan
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 01:12PM sue_blue wrote: I've met with a couple of radiologists and they are recommending treatment. My oncologist is running more tests and said he will "restage" me April 2nd after the team discusses the results of the tests. I had a nuclear bone scan done Tues. and that initiated me having a MRI and CT scans next week. They are trying to zero in on whatever is going on in my hip area. Sometimes this all gets very scary. My hair is about 1/2 inch and starting to get darker also. The eyebrows and eyelashes are still MIA. I am hoping by summer to be able to spike something, because I know the wigs will be way too hot to tolerate. I have stopped wearing a light cotton cap to bed in favor of the new crop of hair that is sprouting. This is all so much more than anyone outside of this sisterhood could comprehend. Thank you all for being here. Susan
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 02:20AM sue_blue wrote: I have been getting really sore in the evenings since the end of radiation. It's very painful to the touch under the breast area and on the sides. My big concern is that the radiation is effecting the TRAM recon. Is the tenderness a usual side effect? Also, how soon after completing rads did everyone begin the tamox? I've given myself almost a week break now; I suppose I'd better take the dive soon. They told me to wait until after rads, but didn't say how long to wait. Does anyone have the site address where you put in everything you've done to combat this disease and it gives you longevity chances and percentages of reocurrance? I'm trying not to worry, but would like to see these figures for myself? I am amazed at those of you that are out gardening and other ambitious activities. I am very tired and am wanting to sleep about half of the day. I have been spending more time with family and friends. My daughter is coming this afternoon for a couple of days. Then she will be taking me to the "procedure" to get my port removed. Blessings to all, Sue

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2008 09:23AM sue_blue wrote: Karen, your talk brought tears to my eyes. This is such a special group of ladies here and no one can take their place. I, too, feel blessed to have found this site and gone through all of this with everyone here. It would have been much more difficult without everyone's support. Isn't it nice to know that the worst of the treatment is over. What was the name of the cookbook/nutrition book?

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2008 03:22AM - edited Jul 10, 2008 03:23AM by sue_blue Kara, how are you doing from the reconstruction you had done? I will be talking with my ps next week about it. Were you off of work for awhile? How are you doing now? I have some extra skin that hangs over the top of my bra under the arm  he wants to take off also. I'm not sure how I feel about more procedures. Tell me what you think?
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2008 03:43AM - edited Oct 12, 2008 03:48AM by sue_blue I had a little scare with the lymph nodes. I found a new lump there. They got me in right away and did an US. I guess they are just lymph nodes, which I thought had been all removed, but evidently still have some floaters. I think I strained my arm carrying a ream of paper around a store for while and that triggered it. It's all I can think of; how sensitive is that? We'll be watching for reactions or evidence of new disease forever. Pretty much life goes on, but this is always on theback burner. We have a gorgeous fall day here, actually the longest stretch of beautiful weather that I can remember. Today might be a good day for dd and kids and I to go to the Pumpkin Patch. I really do appreciate all of you wonderful ladies here. It's comforting to know others know our thought processes and how it is for us. Blessings to all.
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2009 12:16AM sue_blue wrote: I've had an exciting summer so far. When I went in for my 3 month check, they thought my liver was enlarged. But... the CT scan came back clear. Then last week the PS did some revision to the TRAM. I would still like to get the tattoos. I need to check out the lady in Asheville. Do you girls have that done already? Did you get nipples made?  Unsure of how to proceed. Have a great 4th to celebrate our nation's history.
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2009 12:26PM sue_blue wrote: Thanks for the words of encouragement. I had some revision done 2 weeks ago. I had a big fold under the breast area and he fixed that. I've developed an allergy to adhesive and rubber in the binding, I wasn't allergic in all the other surgeries. That was a mess! I had blisters and rash beyond belief. So now after steroids, antibiotics, and an opening that isn't healing correctly... I'm much better. I do want to get the nipples done soon, too, hopefully this year. Kara, your kitchen plans look great. You'll have to post photos you take when it's all completed. We have been having fantastic weather this past week. Today was ideal... 80 and not a lot of humidity. I could take this forever! I have a 3 month check next week. I hope to get through this time without a scare. We have come a long way ladies!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 02:09PM sue_blue wrote: Dear October Friends, It's nice to see this post active again. I like Evy's idea of a get-together in 5 or 10 years. We all need to hold onto that thought. I agree with all of the sentiment about the support here. I don't know how I would have made it through all of that treatment without you dear ones that understood completely what I was going through. You can't really understand what it is all about unless you've walked where we have. Thanks and love to each of you. Cheryl, I'll be praying for benign and checking back for your report. I pray it goes well for you telling your children, and that you are able to enjoy your family and friends this holiday season with a minimum of anxiety. On to a speedy recovery and a good report for you. I see the oncologist on Wednesday, unless the snowstorm prevents that, and the nephrologist later that day. Apparently, the treatments have caused some loss of kidney function. All in all, things are going well and I sincerely pray we can all keep fighting the fight.  Merry Christmas to all, much love, and prayers for health, Sue
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 08:14PM sue_blue wrote: LuAnn,  Being able to see your son may do more for you than anything the onc can do for you right now. As a mother, I know how important it is to see our children and be assured that all is well with them. We need that connection, especially after a tour in Iraq. Hopefully, you can get the pain under control and you will be able to have a wonderful time with your son. Keep us up-to-date so we can send good thoughts and prayers your way for a reunion you so deserve.
Posts.Title: Surgery, SRS or Son in Iraq????? LuAnnH AimeeFaye

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2008 08:08PM sue_blue wrote: Hi everyone, I am more in the Nov group, but your thread is more active and I see some here are at the same place in tx that I am. We have to get the support wherever we can. Hotmedic - I will be getting taxol soon and my case manager said it is hard on the nervous system and could cause some neuropathy. She told me to get a supplement called glutamine in powder form. I am to take 10 grams 3x daily. She said this would help with the se. I hope this helps you some. I get my 4th tx of C/A on Thursday. The 3rd tx was really difficult and makes me very nervous about this next one. Plus, already receiving the heads up about the taxol. I have been so very tired and emotional, more emotional the more tired I become. I'm trying to keep focused on when the tx will be completed and that is this year now. Blessings and health to all in 2008! Susan
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2008 02:43AM sue_blue wrote: Hi everyone, Just had my first taxol yesterday. So far.. so good. I did have a lot more trouble sleeping last night though due to the steroids. My hand feel full and stiff today also. Otherwise, no nausea. Theresa, The AC made me a lot more nauseas and I was very weepy on it. Haven't been on the Taxol long enough to know if the weepy will be different yet. Some of it is everything we have been through and I find my coping skills go way down at night when I'm tired. Hang in there the first few days are the worst and then the symptoms begin to lessen before the next treatment. I'm hoping to avoid weight gain like the rest of you. It has been fluctuating some, but since the beginning of the diagnosis and all the surgeries I've had I've lost around 35 pounds. I'd like to lose maybe 15 more and go with the lifestyle changes. I have some arthritis and high blood pressure and I know my body would really appreciate the changes, as would my husband. He is at his high school weight and has been very disciplined about it over the years. I made it through treatment yesterday without tears, actually the entire day. That's pretty amazing for me. I was at the clinic for 7 hours. Is that how long it take the rest of you? I do start with blood work and then the doctor's visit and finally, the treatment. It's a long day. Congratulations to those of you finishing and looking at completing the reconstruction. There is a light at the end. That's an encouragement to those of us still in process. Blessings to everyone, Susan
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2008 09:17AM sue_blue wrote: Happy Valentine's Day to all the sister! I hope you all get some love from someone is some form. I had my 3rd tx of taxol and came home to a huge bouquet of roses and lillies. My treatment went better this time, a bit less reaction to the dexadron and benadryl. Now waiting to see what the other effects will be. HOpefully less that last time. Only one more to go then I too can do the happy dance. We're getting there girls and the end is in sight.I love the encouraging words from those that have already finished and how they are getting the strength back and starting to travel. WooHoo. Thanks to all of you beautiful ladies and all of your support. I couldn't have made it without you. Blessings to all, Susan

Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2008 12:20PM sue_blue wrote: Amen to no chemo this year. Last year at this time, I wondered if life would ever be normal again. I did get the results of the bone and marrow biopsy today... and it is all good news. It will be a happy Thanksgiving. They tested me for some pretty nasty things. Still uncertain about what is showing up on the bone scans, but it is not lymphoma, leukemia, Paget's disease, etc. I'm pretty good with the results of what it isn't. They continue to monitor the enlarged lymph nodes and I do have regular checks, so I am feeling like I can plan for the future again. Thanks for the concern. On the hair issue... I'm thinking it may be time for a shaping up. I don't really want to cut any off, but feel like it's getting borderline out of control. How is everyone else doing on that subject?

We are so relieved things are returning to her new normal. You can see pictures on FB. I love you girls!

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2008 05:12AM sue_blue wrote: Happy birthday Linda and congrats on the more positive outlook this year. I, too, am trying to avoid soy and HFCS. They do appear to be in everything, but hopefully by avoiding them I can possibly try to lose some weight. I want to be at better BMI to help control this disease also. I guess the tamox and avoidance of soy, HFCS, and a better BMI are what I feel I can do right now to have some power over this. Once I get a little energy back after completing rads, I want to be more regular with the exercise, too. I was exercising regularly last summer before being hit by bc. Keep on keeping on all.

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2008 10:33AM sue_blue wrote: Hi all, I keep getting compliments on my hair also. They say I should keep it short like this; I think not. My husband said he'll let me know when it's long enough to consider stopping. I've never had short hair in my adult life. Mine is also very thick. I have some sort of rash going on the site of the mast and rads. They put me on meds for shingles, but they don't think it looks like classic shingles. I saw three different drs. on Monday. If it isn't gone or much improved by next week, I will probably have to have a biopsy to determine what is going on. That has raised my level of concern. We went to a cancer support group last night that I think we will continue with. They were very supportive and caring; I think it will help my husband with how he processes all of this also. I've started some training for school already and our new curriculum isn't going to be much fun. All teachers teaching the same subject in the district are expected to be in the same place at the same time. Grades 6,7,8 have the same type of consumable workbook for each year, by the time they get to me, in grade 8, I'm afraid they'll be sick of it. I thankful to have a job, but am very concerned about how this will be implemented. Also, starting 10 hour days seems like it will be a lot. Do you all feel back to normal? I'm 2 1/2 months past rads; I thought I was coping better. I think this "rash" has me more undone than I thought.
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2008 10:27AM sue_blue wrote: Karen, my hair is a chestnut color also. I was reddish blonde when I was young, now I am just reddish. I dyed it; I couldn't stand the mousy color that it came in after chemo. I went to the onc today. I've found several lymph nodes that we have been watching. Well, tomorrow they will do a CT scan. He was particularly interested in the ones by my clavicle. I'm also having a bone scan. I wake up frequently during the night with hip pain. I thought it was the tamoxifen, but he didn't think so. Do any of you have bone pain on tamoxifen?  I'll post again when I know the results. We have snow today, 70s yesterday and snow today.

She has a condition called HELLP that can be potentially life-threatenig, it involves very low platelets. The baby's name is Adara Susan, named after me!!! Thank you all of you praying ladies.
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2008 07:39PM sue_blue wrote: I had a bilat mast with tram recon in Oct. of last year. It was a difficult surgery and the recovery was not fun, but today I am glad I went that route. I was always large breasted and couldn't imagine being flat. Also, my MRI showed suspicion of the right breast that would have to be monitored. I see a lot of women on these boards going back in for a propholactic second surgery due to the stress of constant monitoring. I feel more peace knowing that they took as much as possible, minus the few stray cells. There was a concern after the surgery when I had to have radiation that the tram could fail. I was fortunate and that didn't happen, although that side did shrink a bit. If you have more questions that I can help you with, you can post here or PM me. I'm sorry you're going through this, it's a very tough road, but it can be done.  (((Hugs)))
Posts.Title: Tram flap vs bilateral mastectomy Lisa810 browneyes2323

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2008 02:55PM sue_blue wrote: Kristina -- So glad that your scans were clean; what a relief that has to be. You can focus your energy and emotions on more positive things and look forward to life. I'm so happy for you! Deb-- I'm on the same schedule as you as I had my last chemo treatment today. I was dreading going, but I am very glad to be done. I unfortunately had the same reaction to the pre-meds again today. But, got through it and am DONE. The nurses came and sang and brought me a little cake to celebrate. My husband and a friend took me out to dinner to celebrate. It does feel good. The next few days, will be more bearable knowing it will be the last time through on this. Hurray! I have found out that when I go for follow up appts. with the onc, the onc surgeon, and the PS in March they will be doing a follow up bone scan to check for what what glowing in my hip before I began chemo. I'll find out what the team of drs. recommend for radiation and the oral chemo meds. I'm some afraid of them, esp. tamoxifen from what I have been reading. The studies I've read show they really do benefit the chances of reoccurance so onward to what lies ahead. I get so scared thinking about all of this and how out of control it all is. All I really want to do is spend time with my family and close friends. I wish sometimes that I didn't have to work and truly could just be with the ones I love. That doesn't appear to be an option. I've been fortunate to be able to take off the days when I haven't been doing well, working only 3-5 days out of every two weeks and able to keep my full pay and benefits. I know they think I'll be back full-time after this last round. We'll see how the energy levels go. A lot of the things that seemed important before don't seem so much anymore. I just know there a lot of people I care a lot for and they have become even more important to me. You precious ladies here as a support group are right up there at the top. Susan
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 10:42PM sue_blue wrote: Kara, you'll have to update us on the recon. I have that yet to do and haven't read much about it. Did you have bilat? I'm wondering how long the recovery is from that one. I've been getting a lot of positive comments on my hair also. This isn't the style that I would have chosen, but it seems to be working for the time being. Yours looks very nice in your avatar.  TexasKaren, you are really a mover and a shaker as far as being involved in your community. I'm glad you are able to contribute like this; you go girl!  We seem to spend most of our time and energy with our kids. My daughter had a miscarriage last weekend and the other daughter is moving this weekend. It is like this a lot, although you know how it is, you'd do about anything you could for your kids and we have four. Everyone, have a great day and keep up the good fight against bc.
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2008 12:46AM sue_blue wrote: Hi all, just trying to cope with everything. I've been somewhat depressed lately and everything seems more than I can deal with, I just want to pull the covers over my head. I'll need to start back to work in a couple of weeks and am hoping to have the energy to keep up with that. Maybe being around more people will help my mental outlook. My hair is growing, but not very fast. I think it has been an inch and a half for quite awhile. Does anyone else notice increased aches and pains on the tamox?   It is extremely humid here and the heat has been in the 90's. It's fairly miserable outside, but we have been getting regular rains. Our little town of 5000 has been hit this year with a tornado, damaging hail twice, and the arson of a historic building downtown. The fire took out the two neighboring businesses and threatened that whole side of the square. Kara, I'm thinking about just having the 3D tattooing done and skipping the nipple recon. I am so wanting to be done being cut on and put under. In the last 10 months, I've been put under 7 times. Let me know how the tattooing goes, I'll do mine later this year by someone that specializes in tattooing permanent make-up, etc. I'd even like to have eyeliner done, but we'll see about that.
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2008 09:21AM sue_blue wrote: It's my one year anniversary of dx tomorrow.  It's been quite a year; I'm still trying to get some energy back from surgery,rads and chemo. I guess I'll be interested to go to the 3 month check-up in a couple of weeks and see what they do and what they say. I haven't had a check-up yet, just treatments.  So far, the tamox hasn't been too bad. I've learned how to compensate for some of the side effects. I know if I watch what I eat, especially the amount, I have less hot flashing. Tender says if you can lose a bit of weight, it reduces them. I need to work on that one. Not sleeping is not much fun. I do appreciate a good night when I get one. My hair is growing and I've had it shaped twice; get lots of compliments. My husband said he'd let me know when it got long enough; I'm not there yet. I agree that my priorities have really changed. Most of all, I just want to be with the people that I love. The rest doesn't really matter much. I don't post often, but I do truly treasure all of you.  (((Hugs)))

I'll let you know when I find out the results.

Posts.Content: May 19, 2008 07:44AM sue_blue wrote: Texas Karen - was it you that put in the website to figure out the survival rates for the type of BC you have and your treatments? As I'm finishing up rads on Weds. and will be starting Tamoxifen, I am really wanting to try that site again. I feel I need to lose at least 20 more pounds to be at a weight I feel would be comfortable for not producing too much estrogen. Also, dropping some weight might help with the hot flashes for awhile. I am just about to join the nekked head people. I have three more days of being around middle schoolers, then I'm thinking I'm done with the wig. I haven't posted often, but have been following this thread through chemo and rads. We've come through a lot ladies.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2008 08:00AM sue_blue wrote: Texas Karen, I love the video. I want to send it on to my daughters and others. How long have you been done with radiation? How long after rads did your onc say it takes to reach the peak from the tx? I finished rads yesterday. I really was a November chemo gal, so my hair is probably a month behind all of yours. I'm hoping for the curl; I've never had that before. I'm not liking the mousy color that it is though. I get my port out in a week. I was nauseated from the anesthesia putting it in, so am wondering about it coming out, but am ready. We are supposed to leave for Colorado the next morning, so am hoping it goes quickly and well. Are most of you doing the tamoxifen? I know Ulla is struggling, how is it for others? That's next for me. I did read the advice to Ulla to start with smaller doses and build up and think that's what I will do. Keep posting ladies, it helps keep me going. Happy spring to all.

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2008 11:34PM sue_blue wrote: Hi all, it sounds like we are all getting into doing more normal activities and enjoying life again. During that chemo cycle, I wondered if this day would ever come. I see some of you on the tamox boards and wish everyone well in whatever phase they are in. I was told yesterday that I don't need to see the oncologist for three months just for check-ups to make sure the disease stays away. That was a long time in coming. The PS has some tune-up work to do and then I think I'm done with this initial phase, hopefully to never return. I'm getting my hair touched up in a week or so, and then I will post my red hair. Our treatments must have emboldened us and had us step out. I'm hoping for the Jamie Lee Curtis look only in red by fall when I enter a bldg. with 900 middle schoolers. Congratulations to everyone here and how far we have all come on this journey. Especially, those of you that have done public speaking as an encouragement to others. Bravo!
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2009 11:55PM sue_blue wrote: So sorry about you dog, Kara. You've had a hard go of it lately. I am praying you mom is tolerating the treatments and that they will be successful. It is nice to come back here and see that we have made it through the rough part, hopefully permanently. I, too, am doing a Relay for Life this year. My first one. I still have several swollen lymph nodes that we are "watching." I am supposed to have some surgery to fix part of the TRAM flap in July, but the insurance is quibbling... so we'll see. In a way it would be nice to not have another surgery.  Hope everyone can enjoy life this summer to the fullest.
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2010 12:32AM sue_blue wrote: Not on Femara yet. I have one more year on tamoxifen. I'm not looking forward to the AIs as I've had quite a few issues with the tamoxifen. It appears my system did not handle the CT scans and the chemo well. I now have Chronic Kidney Disease stage 3. I had to go off of all the Nsaids for arthritis and watch what I eat for potassium, phosphorous, and limit protein and dairy. Not much left when you consider everything that has soy, also.  We had a wonderful weekend with friends celebrating the Fourth. Saw two excellent fireworks displays. Times like those are encouraging in the struggle. Of course, there is always the family. My daughter and her sons, ages 5 and 10, are living with us, so there's a lot of life and activity going on. Hope you are all holding your own in our ongoing fight against this disease. I think of you often; we are close to the 3 years out mark. That first year during chemo this seemed impossible. Keep up the good fight! (((hugs))) Sue
Posts.Title: October 2007 Chemo Girls 3boys4me saucybee

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2010 01:21PM sue_blue wrote: Congratulations, Karen! We all can celebrate with you in the good news. We are happy for you and it's an encouragement to your chemo friends. The neurological stuff can be weird, but it's better than the alternative. I tried Lyrica for awhile, for fibromyalsia, I can't remember the side effects I had. I just don't do well with anti-depressant types of meds. I know some people have had good results with it. Hopefully, you'll be one of them. Looking forward to that five year out mark when we all get together to celebrate. It makes me smile when I think of it. It will be a blast. I, too, am thankful for each of you and everyday that we can be NED and living life to the fullest. Three years ago we all wondered if we would ever be out among the living again... and here we are. Thanking God also.  Sue

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2008 03:25PM sue_blue wrote: I had the tram in Oct of 2007. I had to have radiation in addition to chemo. They were very concerned that the tram would fail due to the radiation. I came through it fairly well, but the radiated side did shrink some from the tx. I didn't know I would have rads until after the SNB. The tram is a terribly difficult surgery. I was fairly large breasted and was glad that I had something there when I was done with it all. I haven't had nipple recon yet. If DIEP is an option at all for you, I would consider that. Also, I had ILC and the lumpectomy didn't have clean margins; it also has a higher incidence of becoming bilat. These factors influenced my decision. Make sure your surgeon has done a lot of these. Just changing surgeons took the surgery time from 12 hours to 7 hours. If I can help you any more, let me know.
Posts.Title: anyone who's had a tram flap s3434 clmarr

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2008 03:01PM sue_blue wrote: I had the TRAM flap surgery in October. The recovery is difficult, but I did like the idea of using my own tissue instead of foreign objects. I had it done at the same time as the bilat mast. I chose that because ILC has higher risk of being bilat. I do have the scaring, but I now have a flat tummy and the breast size is about a 36c. I will have the nipple recon and tattooing l later this year. Mostly, I am happy I went this route. The only other route I would have considered would no recon. Actually, my first choice would have been the DIEP recon, but I would have had to travel to New Orleans for that. It is a much easier recon.
